newsitem.title: USA: First Union acquisition dilutive in 1997.
newsitem.headline: First Union acquisition dilutive in 1997.

text.p: First Union Corp's purchase of mutual fund company Keystone Investments Inc will dilute earnings by $0.01 or $0.02 per share in 1997 but add to earnings in 18 months, treasurer Kenneth Stancliff said in a conference call with reporters.

The $289 million transaction represents the second biggest purchase of a mutual fund company by a bank. The biggest bank-mutual fund deal on record is Mellon Bank Corp's purchase of the Dreyfus fund group.

To complete the transaction, First Union would issue 2.9 million shares of common stock valued at approximately $183 million, based on Thursday's closing stock price of 62-7/8. First Union would also assume about $106 million of net debt from Keystone. The transaction is expected to close in late 1996 or early 1997.

Albert Elfner III, chairman and chief executive of Keystone Investments, said the significance of the transaction was recognition that the U.S. consumer has clearly started putting savings assets "in a variety of forms away from traditional intermediaries."
